Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: A notice has been posted about an optional training session happening next week.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: During a street demonstration, someone urges them to step past a barricade onto restricted city property.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow as I glanced at the notice tacked to the break room wall—an optional safety training next week. The foreman said it’d help us work better as a team, maybe even keep us safer. I knew the guys expected me to show up, to pull my weight and not slack off. But as I left the site that afternoon, the city was buzzing. A demonstration was swelling down Main Street, voices rising for a cause I believed in. I joined the crowd, feeling the energy, the unity. Suddenly, someone beside me nudged my arm, urging me to step past the barricade onto the city’s restricted property. “We need to make them listen,” he said. My heart pounded. As a citizen, I knew the law—respecting public property, not crossing lines set for safety. But the pressure from the crowd was real, and I could feel the eyes of my fellow workers in my mind, expecting me to stand up for what’s right. I stood there, torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, unsure which expectation I could bear to break.
